awd_titl_txt: EAGER: CFD-based Adjoint Methods for Design Applications with Unsteady Separated Flows
awd_abstract_narration:
A computational method called adjoint based optimization is used in vehicle design to find optimal shapes for desired performance, such enhanced lift or reduced drag of aerodynamic shapes.  Historically, this method has been used on streamlined shapes in simple flow fields, but more recently it has been applied to more complex shapes such as automobiles in complex, turbulent flow fields.  However, the accuracy of the flow simulations and the effectiveness of the design process are unclear. An application where the accuracy of aerodynamic optimization is critical is the Winter Olympic sport of Luge. History has shown that Olympic medals have been determined by time differences of only a few thousandths of a second. The aerodynamics are complicated because the geometry itself is complex and the flow behind the rider/sled involves large scale unsteady turbulent motion (similar to a vehicle). Traditionally luge equipment has been developed by former athletes and was hand shaped based on hunches, feel, and experience. The flow conditions, and historic lack of science based design optimization, make luge sleds an ideal choice for investigation of the effectiveness of adjoint based optimization to perform aerodynamic optimization The successful design, build, and experimentally validating adjoint designs for unsteady flows in this project can potentially have a significant benefit to future designs of cars/trucks, boat/ships, and advanced air vehicles for drag minimization, increased performance during turns/maneuvering, or the prevention of flow separation while accelerating/decelerating.

The goal of this work is to investigate the effectiveness of adjoint methods to reach an optimal shape in turbulent, unsteady, separated flows using experimental validation. An adjoint based method will be developed and applied to a luge sled/rider model that targets modification of the sled shape to minimize drag. Experimental testing will be performed to provide performance data of the intermediate shapes throughout the process to ascertain if the adjoint process is accurately predicting the actual performance and converging towards an optimal solution. The experimental validation will be accomplished by a combination of surface pressure measurement, drag measurement and measurement of the flow fields around the model. Beyond these technical goals is the high-level goal of transferring scientifically optimized race technology to the US Luge Association for use in Olympic competition.

por.por_cntn:
The work focused on using computational methods to automatically design and optimized complex aerodynamic parts. The subject of this work was the optimization of an Olympic luge sled to minimize the drag and give athletes a competitive advantage in Olympic competition. Computer (CAD) models of an actual luge sled and rider were developed from 3D laser scans of the test subject. These CAD models served as the “starting point” for the design process. Computational Fluid Dynamic (CFD) programs were used to calculate the flow fields around the sled and rider to determine the drag value. Additional computer tools (Adjoint Tools) were then used to modify the shape of the sled with a goal of reducing the drag. The same computational tools were also used to guide engineers in making human driven changes to the shape. Meaning the automated design process was stopped before the shape was modified by the adjoint tool, the results were investigated by a designer and the shape was modified by the designer based on the computational results and personal experience. These new shapes were 3D printed and tested in a wind tunnel to confirm the predicted drag values and to determine if the automated process could be used for shape optimization. Wind tunnel experiments were also performed to measure the flow fields to support future development of computational methods. The results of the wind tunnel testing confirmed that both the computer generated and human generated shape modifications resulted in improved drag performance. Both modifications resulted in nearly the same level of drag reduction. However, the computer generated models resulted in modifications that were harder or impractical to manufacture or use. This was because the computer modifications came from pushing or pulling on surfaces which resulted in “wavy” shapes. This was in contrast to the human designs which allowed smooth shape modifications to be made. The wind tunnel results also showed that the accuracy of the computer generated flow fields needs to be improved. Uncertainty in the computational results were found to be greater than the changes in the drag actually measured. Given that the basis for the automated shape process lies in the computer generated flow fields, improvements in the computational results are needed to increase the efficacy of the process. The results of this work shoed that automated computer process shows promise for design of complex aerodynamic shapes, but requires further development to ensure that parts can be manufactured.
